docs.title: FAQ
docs.description: - Which ODBC driver manager is supported? unixODBC on Linux/macOS, Windows ODBC Driver Manager on Windows.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Argus is a production-ready ODBC driver that provides SQL connectivity to multiple big data query engines. It implements the ODBC 3.x API specification with a pluggable backend architecture supporting Apache Hive, Apache Impala, Trino, Apache Phoenix, and Apache Kudu.

docs.title: Projects
docs.description: Welcome to the Varga Foundation docs. We build and support open-source solutions for data and AI that are accessible, ethical, and community-driven.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.description: Kirka configuration is managed via application.properties. Customize before building or override at runtime with Spring Boot external config mechanisms (e.g., --spring.config.location=/path/to/config/).

docs.title: Examples
docs.description: Kirka can be exposed through Apache Knox to provide a single point of entry, authentication, and service discovery.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.description: - Does Kirka provide MLflow UI? No, it is a headless tracking server. Use MLflow clients or integrate with custom UI.

docs.title: Kirka — MLflow-compatible service for Hadoop
docs.description: Kirka is an MLFlow compatible service optimized for the Hadoop ecosystem. It uses HDFS for artifact storage and HBase for metadata and metrics tracking.

docs.title: Building the Mpack
docs.description: The Varga Mpack is built using a provided script that compiles the source code for Kirka and Tarn and bundles them into a single archive.

docs.title: Deployment Guide
docs.description: Once you have built the Mpack, you can install it on your Ambari Server and deploy the services.

docs.title: Ambari Mpack Overview
docs.description: The Varga Management Pack (Mpack) for Apache Ambari allows you to easily deploy and manage Kirka and Tarn services on a Hadoop cluster.

docs.title: Nexberos — Auth & Federation for Data/AI
docs.description: Nexberos provides authentication and federation building blocks tailored for modern data/AI platforms. Goal: simple, secure integration that works well with common tools.

docs.title: Rivio — Data Ingestion and Governance
docs.description: Rivio is a set of tools to orchestrate data ingestion, quality, and governance with a strong focus on lineage, reproducibility, and accessibility.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.description: - What is the recommended load balancing method? Apache Knox + ZooKeeper for production environments with multi-tenancy and high availability. HAProxy + update script for simpler standalone setups.

docs.title: TARN — Triton on YARN
docs.description: TARN is a scalable inference solution for running NVIDIA Triton Inference Server on a Hadoop/YARN cluster using Docker containers.

docs.title: Version compatibility
docs.description: This page lists recommended versions of Kubernetes, CSI components, and Hadoop/HDFS for this driver.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.description: The driver reads its configuration from environment variables and/or a ConfigMap/Secret injected via Helm.

docs.title: Examples
docs.description: This page provides ready-to-use YAML manifests to test the HDFS CSI driver.

docs.title: Vorath — HDFS CSI for Kubernetes
docs.description: Vorath is a CSI plugin that lets Kubernetes workloads mount HDFS volumes through the standard CSI interface. It aims for a simple installation experience, sensible defaults, and smooth production operations.

docs.title: Installation and deployment
docs.description: This page describes how to install the HDFS CSI driver on Kubernetes using Helm. You can use published images or build

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.description: Common symptoms, likely causes, and remediation steps.

docs.title: Weave — Orchestrating Data/AI Workflows
docs.description: Weave is a modular toolkit to orchestrate data and AI workflows. It helps you compose reproducible, observable, and portable steps.

link.description: Production-ready ODBC driver for Hive, Impala...
A Hadoop HRPC protocol implementation for Kubernetes
A Hadoop CRD implmentation for Kubernetes
How to build and deploy Varga services using Ambari Management Packs (Mpack).

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

<!-- truncate -->

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

:::

{/* truncate */}

For example, use JSX to create an interactive button:

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!-- truncate -->
